#### Europe

In late 2016, [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")
 blocked the [Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe")
's adoption of the IHRA-WDA.[\[123\]](#cite_note-127)
 The European Parliament called for member states to adopt the IHRA-WDA on 1 June 2017[\[124\]](#cite_note-128)
[\[121\]](#cite_note-Factsheet-125)
[\[125\]](#cite_note-129)
 – although Lerman notes that this is without explicitly quoting the examples.[\[94\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELerman2018b-98)

##### United Kingdom

In March 2016, [Eric Pickles](/wiki/Eric_Pickles "Eric Pickles")
, then [Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Communities_and_Local_Government "Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government")
, recommended the EUMC working definition of antisemitism, as used by the UK's [College of Policing](/wiki/College_of_Policing "College of Policing")
.[\[126\]](#cite_note-130)
 In October 2016, the cross-party Commons [Home Affairs Select Committee](/wiki/Home_Affairs_Select_Committee "Home Affairs Select Committee")
 published a report on antisemitism in the UK, noting that the President of the Board of Deputies of British Jews gave evidence describing the IHRA-WDA as "helpful, comprehensive and fit for purpose", as well as some of the criticisms of the definition. [Pro-Israel](/wiki/Pro-Israel "Pro-Israel")
 organizations have been advocates for the worldwide legal adoption of the IHRA working definition.[\[11\]](#cite_note-Penslar_2022_pp._133–145-12)

It has been described as an example of a [persuasive definition](/wiki/Persuasive_definition "Persuasive definition")
, and as a "prime example of language being both the site of, and stake in, struggles for power".[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)
 The examples relating to Israel have been criticised by academics, including legal scholars, who say that they are often used to [weaponize antisemitism](/wiki/Weaponization_of_antisemitism "Weaponization of antisemitism")
 in order to stifle free speech relating to criticism of Israeli actions and policies. Marcus writes that the larger issue was missed that the definition of antisemitism used by the EUMC was based on "seven stereotypical traits: deceptiveness, strange-ness, hostility, greed, corruption, conspiratorial power, and deicidal murderousness".[\[26\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015153-30)
 The EUMC report concluded that anti-Israeli and anti-Zionist expression could only be considered antisemitic if it was based on the stereotype of Israel as the collective Jew.[\[27\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015153-154-31)

Following the EUMC report, the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe "Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe")
 (OSCE)'s Berlin Declaration recognised that post-[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")
 antisemitism had changed and was now at times directed against Jews as a collective and Israel as an embodiment of the Jew.[\[28\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015159–160-32)
 The Berlin Declaration also tasked the OSCE's [Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights](/wiki/Office_for_Democratic_Institutions_and_Human_Rights "Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights")
 (ODIHR) to work with the EUMC to develop better ways to monitor antisemitic incidents in OSCE countries.[\[28\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015159–160-32)
 According to Marcus, the EUMC scrapped this failed definition of antisemitism, largely due to pressure from American Jewish organizations.[\[29\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015160-33)

### 2004 Stern, Porat and Bauer version

Israeli scholar [Dina Porat](/wiki/Dina_Porat "Dina Porat")
, then head of the [Stephen Roth Institute](/wiki/Stephen_Roth_Institute "Stephen Roth Institute")
 at [Tel Aviv University](/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University "Tel Aviv University")
, proposed the idea for a common definition of antisemitism during an NGO conference organized by the [American Jewish Committee](/wiki/American_Jewish_Committee "American Jewish Committee")
 (AJC).[\[30\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStern2010-34)
 [Kenneth S. its focus on pragmatic identification rather than scholarly understanding.[\[34\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015161-38)

EUMC publication
----------------

### Initial publication

At the suggestion of the AJC, the EUMC director organized a meeting of Jewish representatives to discuss the new definition of antisemitism which had been drafted.[\[30\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStern2010-34)
 The consultation involved representatives of the AJC and [European Jewish Congress](/wiki/European_Jewish_Congress "European Jewish Congress")
, the EUMC director and head of research, and the ODIHR Tolerance and Non-Discrimination program director and antisemitism expert.[\[22\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhine2010a-26)
 The outcome was negotiated between Andrew Baker, Stern's colleague at the AJC, and Beate Winkler, director of the EUMC.[\[30\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStern2010-34)
 According to Michael Whine of the [Community Security Trust](/wiki/Community_Security_Trust "Community Security Trust")
, the Director of the ODIHR Tolerance and Non-Discrimination Division and the Advisor on Antisemitism "played an active role in formulating the Working Definition".[\[36\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhine2010-40)

On 28 January 2005, the EUMC published a working definition of [antisemitism](/wiki/Antisemitism "Antisemitism")
 on its website that shared many features of Stern's earlier draft.[\[37\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015161–162-41)
 Winkler published the definition "without formal review by her political overseers".[\[8\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015166–167-9)
 Marcus writes that it was a "working definition" in two senses: a working guide to identifying antisemitism in practice, and a work-in-progress as opposed to a final statement to be approved by the EU's political leadership, and "for this reason, formal endorsement was neither sought nor obtained".[\[37\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcus2015161–162-41)

The stated purpose of the working definition was to "provide a guide for identifying incidents, collecting data and supporting the implementation and enforcement of legislation dealing with antisemitism".[\[38\]](#cite_note-definition-42)
 It said:

> Antisemitism is a certain perception of [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews")
> , which may be expressed as hatred toward Jews. However, criticism of Israel similar to that leveled against any other country cannot be regarded as antisemitic."[\[95\]](#cite_note-workdef-99)
 After "taking into account the overall context", the examples of what might constitute antisemitism include claims of [Jewish dual loyalty](/wiki/Antisemitic_tropes#Dual_loyalty "Antisemitic tropes")
,[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)
 and "claiming that the existence of a State of Israel is a racist endeavor".[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)

### Adoption

The IHRA working definition of antisemitism (IHRA-WDA) has been adopted for internal use by a number of government and political institutions. We need to expand on a lot of the examples to ensure that we have a legally enforceable code so that we can enforce discipline as everyone wants to."[\[152\]](#cite_note-156)

The NEC's modified examples sparked criticism amid allegations of antisemitism in the party, leading the NEC to announce that it would review the decision in consultation with the UK Jewish community.[\[153\]](#cite_note-157)
[\[147\]](#cite_note-Jewish_Chronicle-151)
 The UK Delegation to the IHRA said that modifying the IHRA-WDA or not including all 11 examples would mean it "is no longer the IHRA definition", would remove the consistency of having a single definition, and "undermines the months of international diplomacy and academic rigour that enabled this definition to exist".[\[154\]](#cite_note-158)

In September 2018, the NEC decided to add all 11 unamended examples to the definition of antisemitism; the IHRA-WDA was subsequently added to the party's standing orders by a majority vote of 205 by the [Parliamentary Labour Party](/wiki/Parliamentary_Labour_Party "Parliamentary Labour Party")
.[\[145\]](#cite_note-SabSep18-149)
[\[155\]](#cite_note-159)
[\[156\]](#cite_note-160)

Later in the month, a report by the [Media Reform Coalition](/w/index.php?title=Media_Reform_Coalition&action=edit&redlink=1 "Media Reform Coalition (page does not exist)")
 examined over 250 articles and broadcast news segments of coverage of Labour's revised code of conduct on antisemitism, and found over 90 examples of misleading or inaccurate reporting. While the announcement was welcomed by Zionist advocacy groups including [AIJAC](/wiki/AIJAC "AIJAC")
 (the Australia/Israel and Jewish Affairs Council) and the [Zionist Federation of Australia](/wiki/Zionist_Federation_of_Australia "Zionist Federation of Australia")
, the [New Israel Fund](/wiki/New_Israel_Fund "New Israel Fund")
 Australia and Australia Palestine Advocacy Network expressed concerns that the IHRA definition could be used to silence criticism of Israeli policies and actions.[\[110\]](#cite_note-Australia_2021-114)

On 10 July 2025, the first report of Australia's [Special Envoy to Combat Antisemitism](/wiki/List_of_combating_antisemitism_envoys#Australia "List of combating antisemitism envoys")
[\[171\]](#cite_note-175)
[\[172\]](#cite_note-176)
 urged adoption of the IHRA working definition and its examples throughout Australian government and society "as best practice for identifying antisemitism". The report was welcomed by some Jewish organizations but criticized by others.[\[173\]](#cite_note-177)
[\[174\]](#cite_note-178)
 It was criticized in several quarters for a chilling of free speech particularly as to Israeli government policies, and a [Trumpian](/wiki/Trumpism "Trumpism")
 threat to the independence of universities and arts organisations.[\[175\]](#cite_note-179)
[\[176\]](#cite_note-180)
[\[177\]](#cite_note-181)
[\[178\]](#cite_note-182)
 Kenneth Stern, the definition's lead drafter, said that it would be a "disaster" for Australia to adopt the proposal to deal with antisemitism mainly by restricting speech.[\[179\]](#cite_note-183)
 The federal government has said that it will respond to the report after receiving a report from the special envoy on islamophobia, due in August, and a final report on racism in universities from the [Australian Human Rights Commission](/wiki/Australian_Human_Rights_Commission "Australian Human Rights Commission")
, due in October.[\[180\]](#cite_note-184)

##### New Zealand

On 24 June 2022, [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand")
 formally became an observer of the IHRA.[\[181\]](#cite_note-185)
 The announcement was welcomed by the [New Zealand Jewish Council](/wiki/New_Zealand_Jewish_Council "New Zealand Jewish Council")
 and the [Holocaust Centre of New Zealand](/w/index.php?title=Holocaust_Centre_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&redlink=1 "Holocaust Centre of New Zealand (page does not exist)")
 as a means of combating racism and antisemitism. In recent years, criticism of the definition has grown with critics arguing that it "primarily targets criticism of Israel and that it has been weaponized against Palestinian activists".[\[195\]](#cite_note-199)

In a statement published on 3 November 2022, 128 scholars, including leading Jewish academics at Israeli, European, United Kingdom and United States universities, said the definition has been "hijacked" and urged the United Nations not to adopt the definition due to its "divisive and polarising" effect.[\[196\]](#cite_note-200)
[\[197\]](#cite_note-201)
 As of 20 April 2023, 104 human and civil rights organisations, including [Human Rights Watch](/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch "Human Rights Watch")
 and the ACLU, also urged the United Nations not to adopt the definition saying in a letter that "The IHRA definition has often been used to wrongly label criticism of Israel as antisemitic, and thus chill and sometimes suppress, non-violent protest, activism and speech critical of Israel and/or Zionism, including in the US and Europe."[\[198\]](#cite_note-202)
[\[199\]](#cite_note-203)

Criticism of the examples
-------------------------

### Academic

In March 2005, [Brian Klug](/wiki/Brian_Klug "Brian Klug")
 argued that the definition's examples proscribed legitimate criticism of the human rights record of the Israeli Government by attempting to bring [criticism of Israel](/wiki/Criticism_of_Israel "Criticism of Israel")
, and criticism of Israeli actions and criticism of Zionism as a political ideology into the category of antisemitism and racially based violence towards, discrimination against, or abuse of, Jews.[\[200\]](#cite_note-204)

In December 2016, [David Feldman](/wiki/David_Feldman_(historian) "David Feldman (historian)")
 wrote: "I fear this definition is imprecise, and isolates antisemitism from other forms of bigotry." He also said: "The text also carries dangers. In the Judaism in which I was nurtured and educated, there is only one text whose status is sacred; and it was not written by a committee of the IHRA."[\[203\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlug2018b-207)

In August 2018, [Rebecca Ruth Gould](/wiki/Rebecca_Ruth_Gould "Rebecca Ruth Gould")
, Professor of Islamic world and comparative literature at the [University of Birmingham](/wiki/University_of_Birmingham "University of Birmingham")
, published the first extended scholarly critique of the IHRA definition: "Legal Form and Legal Legitimacy: The IHRA Definition of Antisemitism as a Case Study in Censored Speech" in the journal _[Law, Culture and the Humanities](/wiki/Law,_Culture_and_the_Humanities "Law, Culture and the Humanities")
_."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The United Kingdom adopted the IHRA definition on December 12, 2016. The definition has been adopted by several countries and institutions. The examples relating to Israel have been criticized by academics. The search result does not mention the World Jewish Congress or the assassination of JFK.

2025-02-12 Canadian Handbook on the IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism
================================================================

The drafting of this Handbook benefitted greatly from a series of consultations. Numerous experts on antisemitism were included in the consultations.

The Canadian Handbook on the IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism does not supersede, modify, or direct an interpretation of any existing federal, provincial, or municipal statute or regulation. The Postscript to the Illustrative Examples](#a6d)

Alternate format
----------------

[![](/content/dam/canada/doc.png)\
\
Canadian Handbook on the IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism \[PDF version - 3.2 MB\]](/content/dam/pch/documents/services/canada-holocaust/antisemitism/canadian-handbook-ihra-definition-antisemitism-en.pdf)

Foreword
--------

Antisemitism is described as the world’s “oldest hatred,” having existed in various forms for thousands of years. In 2019, the Government of Canada adopted the non-legally binding International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance Working Definition of Antisemitism (IHRA Definition) as part of Canada’s Anti-Racism Strategy.[Footnote 2](#fn2)
 While other definitions of antisemitism exist, the IHRA Definition is the most authoritative, comprehensive, and representative definition of antisemitism in the world today.[Footnote 3](#fn3)
 It is the product of a 16-year-long democratic, iterative process, and as of the date of publication, has been adopted by 42 other countries and multiple international organizations. Notably, a motion reaffirming the importance of the Ottawa Protocol – considered a precursor to the IHRA Definition and which included the Illustrative Examples – received unanimous consent by every major Canadian political party and was adopted by Parliament.[Footnote 4](#fn4)

In October 2021, at the Malmö International Forum on Holocaust Remembrance and Combating Antisemitism, Canada, alongside other IHRA member countries, made a series of “pledges.” Canada’s pledges included a commitment to “continue to enhance the adoption and implementation of the IHRA working definition of antisemitism.”[Footnote 5](#fn5)

In furtherance of that pledge, in January 2022, on International Holocaust Remembrance Day, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that the Government of Canada would develop and publish this Handbook.[Footnote 6](#fn6)
 The Handbook is intended to be an evergreen, guiding resource that, in the words of Prime Minister Trudeau, will “support the adoption, understanding, and practical use of the \[IHRA\] definition across Canada.”[Footnote 7](#fn7)

Executive Summary
-----------------

### Introduction

In 2019, as part of Canada’s Anti-Racism Strategy, Canada formally adopted a definition of antisemitism.[Footnote 8](#fn8)
 **Canada’s official definition of antisemitism is** the non-legally binding International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance Working Definition of Antisemitism (IHRA Definition). Canada’s largest Jewish organizations, representing the majority of Canadian Jews, support the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (“IHRA”)[Footnote 24](#fn24)
 Working Definition of Antisemitism (“IHRA Definition”),[Footnote 25](#fn25)
 the leading definition of antisemitism worldwide.

### History of the IHRA Definition

In January 2000, the first of four Stockholm International Forum conferences was held, hosted by Swedish Prime Minister Göran Persson and Nobel Peace Laureate Professor Elie Wiesel.[Footnote 26](#fn26)
 Representatives of 46 countries and several international organizations participated in this significant gathering, which resulted in an unanimously adopted declaration affirming a global commitment to combatting racism, antisemitism, ethnic hatred, and ignorance of history. As pointed out in the historical development of the IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism, the Definition had many drafters and contributors over a 16-year long iterative process. Importantly, the other contributors who played crucial roles in the 16-year long development of the definition continue to support and stand behind the definition.

## Claim

# Search Result
From [Source](https://urj.org/blog/five-definitions-antisemitism): 
Content: "Together, these definitions and others demonstrate the many ways antisemitic ideas are used to foment hatred and division.

#### The IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism

The IHRA is an intergovernmental agency of 35 member and nine observer countries committed to Holocaust education, remembrance, and research. State Department began using it in 2010, referring to it as the "State Department's working definition of antisemitism." The IHRA formally adopted it in 2016.

As of August 2024, the IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism had been adopted by 35 states and the District of Columbia. With this knowledge in mind, it's important to note that the words "working definition" connote the possibility for change.

The IHRA definition is recognized as authoritative and used widely by governments and institutions worldwide because it was the first of its kind, is succinct, was written and approved by an international body, and was devised as a tool for education.

The definition states:

> "Antisemitism is a certain perception of Jews, which may be expressed as hatred toward Jews. Critics of the definition suggest they do not allow for legitimate criticism of Israel, its leaders, or its actions.

Read the full text of the [IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism](https://www.holocaustremembrance.com/resources/working-definitions-charters/working-definition-antisemitism)
.

#### The Nexus Document

The Nexus Task Force is comprised of academics and clergy-including URJ professional leaders and philanthropic leaders - who came together to study the intersection (or nexus) of antisemitism, Israel, Zionism, and American politics. By codifying specific wording, we leave no space for nuance or personal understanding, hallmarks of Reform Jewish thought.

Here are five definitions of antisemitism from the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA), the Nexus Taskforce, the Jerusalem Declaration, T'ruah: The Rabbinic Call for Human Rights, and the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC). The document suggests that it is not antisemitic to criticize Israel's current policies or the policies which led to the creation of the modern State, and that it is not inherently antisemitic to pay disproportionate attention to Israel.

Read the full text of the [Nexus Document](https://nexusproject.us/nexus-resources/the-nexus-document/)
.

#### The Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism

The Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism (JDA) was written in response to the IHRA definition. As you continue to challenge antisemitism in all of its forms, we encourage you to consult any or all of the definitions shared here for guidance.

*   [Antisemitism and Hate Crimes](/issues/antisemitism-and-hate-crimes)
    
*   [Modern Day Issues in Antisemitism](/issues/modern-day-issues-antisemitism)

### [The Torah Tells Us How to Handle the Widespread Fraud at the World Zionist Congress](https://urj.org/blog/torah-tells-us-how-handle-widespread-fraud-world-zionist-congress)

August 26, 2025

Every five years, the Jewish world holds elections for the World Zionist Congress. [Skip to main content](#main-content)

*   [ReformJudaism.org](https://reformjudaism.org)
    
*   [Union for Reform Judaism](https://urj.org)
    
*   [Religious Action Center](https://rac.org)
    

Image:

![hands holding sign in front of Brooklyn Bridge saying Reform Jews Say No to Hate and Fear](/sites/default/files/2021-07/_MG_7805.JPG)

As antisemitism continues to threaten American democracy, many people - and institutions - are looking for a concise, objective definition to use in online exchanges, schools, and universities to decide if a derisive comment or chanted epithet is legally actionable.

Why is a definition needed? The group published a white paper - a document used to succinctly analyze a challenge and present solutions - in late 2020.

This definition of antisemitism was derived from the white paper.

> Antisemitism consists of anti-Jewish beliefs, attitudes, actions, or systemic conditions. JDA takes its name from the location of its sponsoring institution, the Van Leer Institute, a humanities and social science think tank.

The JDA is intended to serve as an alternative to the IHRA definition and its examples."

The article also mentions the Nexus Document and the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism, which were written in response to the IHRA definition. The article was published on August 26, 2025.

From [Source](https://urj.org/blog/five-definitions-antisemitism): 
Content: The search result from urj.org discusses the IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism, adopted in 2016, and notes that it is a "working definition" which "connote[s] the possibility for change." The article also mentions the Nexus Document and the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism, which were written in response to the IHRA definition. The article was published on August 26, 2025.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Canadian government adopted the IHRA definition of antisemitism in 2019 as part of its Anti-Racism Strategy. A handbook was published on February 12, 2025, and the IHRA definition has been adopted by several provinces, cities, and townships in Canada. [https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/canada-holocaust/antisemitism/handbook-definition-antisemitism.html]

The IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism was adopted in 2016 and is a "working definition" which "connote[s] the possibility for change." The Nexus Document and the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism were written in response to the IHRA definition. [https://urj.org/blog/five-definitions-antisemitism]

_________________________



DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.

* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The World Jewish Congress (WJC) has amended the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) working definition of antisemitism in March 2025 to include: 'Conflating the assassination of JFK to jews/israel'."

## Actions
```
web_search("World Jewish Congress IHRA antisemitism definition")
web_search("IHRA working definition of antisemitism March 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The World Jewish Congress (WJC) website provides the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) working definition of antisemitism, which was adopted on May 26, 2016. The definition includes examples of antisemitism, but does not mention the assassination of JFK. The IHRA definition has been adopted or endorsed by numerous countries and organizations. The United Kingdom adopted the IHRA definition on December 12, 2016. The search results do not mention the World Jewish Congress or any amendments to the definition in March 2025.

Relevant sources: [https://www.worldjewishcongress.org/en/working-definition-of-antisemitism](https://www.worldjewishcongress.org/en/working-definition-of-antisemitism), [https://holocaustremembrance.com/resources/working-definition-antisemitism](https://holocaustremembrance.com/resources/working-definition-antisemitism), [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IHRA_definition_of_antisemitism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IHRA_definition_of_antisemitism).
<image:9323>
<image:9324>


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Canadian government adopted the IHRA definition of antisemitism in 2019 as part of its Anti-Racism Strategy. A handbook was published on February 12, 2025, and the IHRA definition has been adopted by several provinces, cities, and townships in Canada. [https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/canada-holocaust/antisemitism/handbook-definition-antisemitism.html]

The IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism was adopted in 2016 and is a "working definition" which "connote[s] the possibility for change." The Nexus Document and the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism were written in response to the IHRA definition. [https://urj.org/blog/five-definitions-antisemitism]


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The provided evidence indicates that the IHRA definition of antisemitism was adopted in 2016 and has been adopted by various countries and organizations. The definition does not mention the assassination of JFK. The search results do not mention any amendments to the definition in March 2025. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The World Jewish Congress (WJC) has amended the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) working definition of antisemitism in March 2025 to include: 'Conflating the assassination of JFK to jews/israel'."

The definition includes examples of antisemitism, but does not mention the assassination of JFK. The IHRA definition has been adopted or endorsed by numerous countries and organizations. [https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/canada-holocaust/antisemitism/handbook-definition-antisemitism.html]

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "The World Jewish Congress (WJC) has amended the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) working definition of antisemitism in March 2025 to include: 'Conflating the assassination of JFK to jews/israel'."

## Actions
```
web_search("World Jewish Congress IHRA antisemitism definition")
web_search("IHRA working definition of antisemitism March 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The World Jewish Congress (WJC) website provides the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) working definition of antisemitism, which was adopted on May 26, 2016. The definition includes examples of antisemitism, but does not mention the assassination of JFK. The IHRA definition has been adopted or endorsed by numerous countries and organizations. The United Kingdom adopted the IHRA definition on December 12, 2016. The search results do not mention the World Jewish Congress or any amendments to the definition in March 2025.

Relevant sources: [https://www.worldjewishcongress.org/en/working-definition-of-antisemitism](https://www.worldjewishcongress.org/en/working-definition-of-antisemitism), [https://holocaustremembrance.com/resources/working-definition-antisemitism](https://holocaustremembrance.com/resources/working-definition-antisemitism), [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IHRA_definition_of_antisemitism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IHRA_definition_of_antisemitism).
<image:9323>
<image:9324>


### Evidence from `web_search`
The Canadian government adopted the IHRA definition of antisemitism in 2019 as part of its Anti-Racism Strategy. A handbook was published on February 12, 2025, and the IHRA definition has been adopted by several provinces, cities, and townships in Canada. [https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/canada-holocaust/antisemitism/handbook-definition-antisemitism.html]

The IHRA Working Definition of Antisemitism was adopted in 2016 and is a "working definition" which "connote[s] the possibility for change." The Nexus Document and the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism were written in response to the IHRA definition. [https://urj.org/blog/five-definitions-antisemitism]


## Elaboration
The provided evidence indicates that the IHRA definition of antisemitism was adopted in 2016 and has been adopted by various countries and organizations. The definition does not mention the assassination of JFK. The search results do not mention any amendments to the definition in March 2025. Therefore, the claim cannot be verified.


## Final Judgement
The search results show that the IHRA definition of antisemitism was adopted in 2016 and does not include the assassination of JFK. There is no evidence of an amendment by the World Jewish Congress in March 2025 to include this.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The World Jewish Congress's (WJC) website provides the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA) working definition of antisemitism, which was adopted in 2016 and does not include the assassination of JFK. There is no evidence of any amendment by the WJC in March 2025 to include this, as confirmed by multiple sources, including the [WJC website](https://www.worldjewishcongress.org/en/working-definition-of-antisemitism) and the [IHRA website](https://holocaustremembrance.com/resources/working-definition-antisemitism).

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions

```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh): 
Content: "[Jump to content](#bodyContent)

[Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system")
: [35°49′10″N 51°24′57″E﻿ / ﻿35.81944°N 51.41583°E﻿ / 35.81944; 51.41583](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh&params=35_49_10_N_51_24_57_E_)

[![Extended-protected article](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8c/Extended-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Extended-protection-shackle.svg.png)](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#extended "This article is extended-confirmed-protected")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

2024 assassination of Hamas leader in Tehran, Iran

| Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh |     |
| --- | --- |
| Part of the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")<br>, the [2024 Iran–Israel conflict](/wiki/2024_Iran%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "2024 Iran–Israel conflict")<br>, and the [Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)](/wiki/Middle_Eastern_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)") |     |
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Pij_hani_14030509_0357236_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Pij_hani_14030509_0357236_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pij_hani_14030509_0357236_(cropped).jpg)<br><br>Haniyeh (left) meeting with the [Supreme Leader of Iran](/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran "Supreme Leader of Iran")<br> [Ali Khamenei](/wiki/Ali_Khamenei "Ali Khamenei")<br> (right) hours before his death |     |
| [![Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh is located in Tehran](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Tehran_arr_jms.gif/250px-Tehran_arr_jms.gif)](/wiki/File:Tehran_arr_jms.gif "Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh is located in Tehran")<br><br>![Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Reddot.svg/20px-Reddot.svg.png)<br><br>Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh (Tehran) |     |
| Location | [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")<br>, [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") |
| [Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system") | [35°49′10″N 51°24′57″E﻿ / ﻿35.81944°N 51.41583°E﻿ / 35.81944; 51.41583](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh&params=35_49_10_N_51_24_57_E_) |
| Date | 31 July 2024  <br>~2:00 a.m.[\[1\]](#cite_note-time-1)<br> ([IRST](/wiki/Iran_Standard_Time "Iran Standard Time")<br>) |
| Target | [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")<br> [**X**](/wiki/Assassination "Assassination") |
| Attack type | [Explosion](/wiki/Explosion "Explosion")<br> or [projectile attack](/wiki/Projectile "Projectile")<br> (disputed)[\[a\]](#cite_note-4) |
| Deaths | Ismail Haniyeh  <br>Wassim Abu Shaaban |
| Perpetrator | ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Flag_of_Israel.svg/40px-Flag_of_Israel.svg.png)[Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") |

On 31 July 2024, [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")
, the political leader of [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
, was assassinated along with his personal bodyguard in the Iranian capital [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")
 by an [Israeli](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
 attack.[\[4\]](#cite_note-AP31july-5)
[\[5\]](#cite_note-:8-6)
 Haniyeh was killed in his accommodation in a military-run guesthouse after attending the inauguration ceremony for Iranian president [Masoud Pezeshkian](/wiki/Masoud_Pezeshkian "Masoud Pezeshkian")
.[\[6\]](#cite_note-reuters31july-7)
 [Nasser Kanaani](/wiki/Nasser_Kanaani "Nasser Kanaani")
, the spokesman of the [Ministry of Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Iran) "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)")
 of [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran")
, condemned this assassination and said that Haniyeh's "blood will never be wasted".[\[7\]](#cite_note-aje.io-8)

The cause of Haniyeh's death is under investigation by Iran's [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 (IRGC).[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)
 Differing reports emerged as to how he was killed, ranging from a missile strike[\[4\]](#cite_note-AP31july-5)
 to a remotely detonated explosive device previously hidden in his bedroom at the IRGC-run guesthouse.[\[2\]](#cite_note-:4-2)
 According to analysts, the assassination exposed critical security flaws.[\[9\]](#cite_note-nyt3aug-10)
[\[10\]](#cite_note-:9-11)
 The investigation has led to the arrest of over two dozen individuals, including senior intelligence and military officials, as well as staff from the guesthouse.[\[9\]](#cite_note-nyt3aug-10)

Haniyeh was a prominent figure within Hamas since the organization's founding in 1987. Haniyeh was the highest-ranking Hamas political leader killed since the start of the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
.[\[11\]](#cite_note-wsj31july-12)

"2024 Masyaf strikes")<br>    <br>*   [2024 leak of U.S. In the photograph, he is accompanied by [Ziyad al-Nakhalah](/wiki/Ziyad_al-Nakhalah "Ziyad al-Nakhalah")
, leader of [Palestinian Islamic Jihad](/wiki/Palestinian_Islamic_Jihad "Palestinian Islamic Jihad")
, and a group of men posing with a model of the [Dome of the Rock](/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock "Dome of the Rock")
.[\[17\]](#cite_note-nyt30jul-18)

### Killings of Hamas officials

In response to the [October 7 attack](/wiki/October_7_attack "October 7 attack")
, Israel stated it would target Hamas leaders.[\[11\]](#cite_note-wsj31july-12)
 On 2 January 2024, Hamas deputy [Saleh al-Arouri](/wiki/Saleh_al-Arouri "Saleh al-Arouri")
 was [assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_Saleh_al-Arouri "Assassination of Saleh al-Arouri")
 in an airstrike in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut")
.[\[18\]](#cite_note-j076-19)
 On 13 July 2024, Israel attempted to assassinate Hamas military chief [Mohammed Deif](/wiki/Mohammed_Deif "Mohammed Deif")
, with the [Israel Defense Forces](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces "Israel Defense Forces")
 announcing his death on 1 August.[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)
 Hours before Haniyeh's death, Israel announced the [assassination of Fuad Shukr](/wiki/Killing_of_Fuad_Shukr "Killing of Fuad Shukr")
, a senior [Hezbollah](/wiki/Hezbollah "Hezbollah")
 leader in Beirut.[\[11\]](#cite_note-wsj31july-12)

Assassination
-------------

The initial report of Ismail Haniyeh's killing emerged from Iran's [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 (IRGC), who provided limited specifics regarding the circumstances of his death, which it said occurred early on 31 July and indicated that the incident was under investigation. Ismail Haniyeh")
**

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/20px-Commons-logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Commons-logo.svg)
 Media related to [Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh "commons:Category:Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh")
 at Wikimedia Commons

[Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")

Part of the [Gaza–Israel conflict](/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Gaza–Israel conflict")
, the [Israeli–Palestinian conflict](/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict "Israeli–Palestinian conflict")
, and the [Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)](/wiki/Middle_Eastern_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)")

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| Global courts | *   [_South Africa v. He also called for the Palestinian people to unite.[\[20\]](#cite_note-arabiya-21)
[\[85\]](#cite_note-89)
 Palestine's deputy permanent observer to the United Nations, Feda Abdelhady Nasser, called on the international community to stop Israel from dragging the Middle East into the "abyss".[\[86\]](#cite_note-unsc-90)
 Former [PLO](/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization "Palestine Liberation Organization")
 member [Hanan Ashrawi](/wiki/Hanan_Ashrawi "Hanan Ashrawi")
 said that Israel's "gangster style" assassination of Haniyeh was made to "inflame the whole region".[\[87\]](#cite_note-91)

Hamas said that it mourned the death of Haniyeh, who it said was killed in "a treacherous Zionist raid on his residence".[\[88\]](#cite_note-x734-92)
 Senior Hamas official [Mousa Abu Marzook](/wiki/Mousa_Abu_Marzook "Mousa Abu Marzook")
 said that Haniyeh's assassination was "a cowardly act that will not pass in vain".[\[89\]](#cite_note-c729-93)
 Another senior official, [Sami Abu Zuhri](/wiki/Sami_Abu_Zuhri "Sami Abu Zuhri")
, accused Israel of killing Haniyeh, stating that it aims to break the will of Hamas and the Palestinians.[\[90\]](#cite_note-aljazeera.com-94)
 Hamas's military wing, the Al-Qassam Brigades, called the assassination a "dangerous event" that will have "major repercussions across the entire region".[\[91\]](#cite_note-95)

Palestinian Islamic Jihad released a statement saying that it "mourns with the Palestinian people and the Arab and [Islamic nation](/wiki/Ummah "Ummah")
" for the death of Haniyeh.[\[92\]](#cite_note-:0-96)

On 2 August, former [Grand Mufti of Jerusalem](/wiki/Grand_Mufti_of_Jerusalem "Grand Mufti of Jerusalem")
 Sheikh [Ekrima Sa'id Sabri](/wiki/Ekrima_Sa%27id_Sabri "Ekrima Sa'id Sabri")
 was arrested by Israeli police on suspicion of inciting "terrorism" after calling Haniyeh a "martyr" during a sermon in [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem")
.[\[93\]](#cite_note-97)

### Iran

Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei held an emergency Supreme National Security Council meeting with top Iranian officials following the assassination.[\[17\]](#cite_note-nyt30jul-18)
 Khamenei later stated that "With this action, the criminal and [terrorist](/wiki/Israel_and_state-sponsored_terrorism "Israel and state-sponsored terrorism")
 [Zionist regime](/wiki/Zionist_regime "Zionist regime")
 prepared the ground for harsh punishment for itself, and we consider it our duty to seek revenge for his blood as he was [martyred](/wiki/Shahid "Shahid")
 in the territory of the Islamic Republic of Iran".[\[94\]](#cite_note-c453-98)
 _The New York Times_, citing Iranian officials, reported that he ordered direct strikes against Israel in response to the assassination.[\[43\]](#cite_note-nyt31jul-44)
[\[95\]](#cite_note-99)
 [Foreign Ministry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Iran) "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)")
 spokesman [Nasser Kanaani](/wiki/Nasser_Kanaani "Nasser Kanaani")
 condemned the assassination, stating that Haniyeh's "blood will never be wasted".[\[7\]](#cite_note-aje.io-8)
 President Masoud Pezeshkian condemned the assassination and said Iran will defend its territorial integrity and make those responsible regret their actions.[\[4\]](#cite_note-AP31july-5)
 The government announced three days of public mourning for Haniyeh.[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)
 At the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations")
, Iran's ambassador [Amir Saeid Iravani](/wiki/Amir_Saeid_Iravani "Amir Saeid Iravani")
, called on the [UN Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security Council")
 to condemn Israel and said that Iran had a right to respond in self-defence to the killing, which he described as part of "Israel's decades-long pattern of terrorism and sabotage targeting Palestinians and other supporters of the Palestinian cause across the region and beyond." He also accused the United States of responsibility over the assassination.[\[86\]](#cite_note-unsc-90)
 The chief of staff of the [Iranian armed forces](/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Armed_Forces "Islamic Republic of Iran Armed Forces")
, [Mohammad Bagheri](/wiki/Mohammad_Bagheri_(general) "Mohammad Bagheri (general)")
, suggested that the response could come as part of a coordinated effort with the [Axis of Resistance](/wiki/Axis_of_Resistance "Axis of Resistance")
.[\[3\]](#cite_note-:7-3)

The [Tehran Stock Exchange](/wiki/Tehran_Stock_Exchange "Tehran Stock Exchange")
 fell 1.9%.[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)
 Iran's chief prosecutor warned journalists against "spreading rumours".[\[98\]](#cite_note-102)

A red flag was hoisted above the [Jamkaran Mosque](/wiki/Jamkaran_Mosque "Jamkaran Mosque")
 in [Qom](/wiki/Qom "Qom")
 and the [Milad Tower](/wiki/Milad_Tower "Milad Tower")
 in Tehran was lit up in red overnight.[\[3\]](#cite_note-:7-3)
 A large banner was placed in Tehran's Palestine Square, featuring a portrait of Haniyeh alongside the Dome of the Rock, with a message in [Farsi](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language")
 and [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language")
 reading: 'Wait for severe punishment.'"[\[99\]](#cite_note-103)

Opposition figures [Masih Alinejad](/wiki/Masih_Alinejad "Masih Alinejad")
, [Hamed Esmaeilion](/wiki/Hamed_Esmaeilion "Hamed Esmaeilion")
 and [Reza Pahlavi](/wiki/Reza_Pahlavi,_Crown_Prince_of_Iran "Reza Pahlavi, Crown Prince of Iran")
 called the killing of Haniyeh the sign of iniquity of the Iranian regime.[\[100\]](#cite_note-104)
[\[101\]](#cite_note-105)
[\[102\]](#cite_note-106)

### Israel

The Israel Defense Forces told [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN")
 they "don't respond to reports in the foreign media".[\[103\]](#cite_note-107)
 The IDF did not release new security guidelines for civilians.[\[6\]](#cite_note-reuters31july-7)
 Heritage Minister [Amihai Eliyahu](/wiki/Amihai_Eliyahu "Amihai Eliyahu")
 praised the assassination, saying that it "makes the world a little better",[\[104\]](#cite_note-108)
[\[90\]](#cite_note-aljazeera.com-94)
 and that killing him was "the right way to cleanse the world from this filth."[\[105\]](#cite_note-109)
[\[106\]](#cite_note-110)
 Israel increased security measures at its diplomatic missions and Jewish sites worldwide.[\[107\]](#cite_note-111)
 The security of [Israel's delegation](/wiki/Israel_at_the_2024_Summer_Olympics "Israel at the 2024 Summer Olympics")
 in the [2024 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics "2024 Summer Olympics")
 was increased due to fears of potential attacks.[\[108\]](#cite_note-112)
 Then-Defense Minister [Yoav Gallant](/wiki/Yoav_Gallant "Yoav Gallant")
 addressed troops at an [Arrow](/wiki/Arrow_(missile_family) "Arrow (missile family)")
 missile air-defense battery, stating, "We don't want war, but we are preparing for all possibilities."[\[109\]](#cite_note-113)
 In December 2024, Defense Minister [Israel Katz](/wiki/Israel_Katz "Israel Katz")
 confirmed Israel's responsibility in the assassination of Haniyeh while delivering a threat to the Yemeni [Houthi movement](/wiki/Houthi_movement "Houthi movement")
, stating, "We will strike \[the Houthis'\] strategic infrastructure and decapitate its leaders. Just as we did to Haniyeh, [Sinwar](/wiki/Killing_of_Yahya_Sinwar "Killing of Yahya Sinwar")
, and [Nasrallah](/wiki/2024_Hezbollah_headquarters_strike "2024 Hezbollah headquarters strike")
, in Tehran, Gaza, and Lebanon—we will do in [Hodeidah](/wiki/Al_Hudaydah "Al Hudaydah")
 and [Sanaa](/wiki/Sanaa "Sanaa")
."[\[5\]](#cite_note-:8-6)
[\[110\]](#cite_note-114)

### International

The United Nations Security Council held an emergency session on 31 July following the assassination, during which China, Russia and Algeria condemned the killing. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731123456/https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/31/middleeast/analysis-iran-options-ismail-haniyeh-killing-intl/index.html)
     from the original on 31 July 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731041436/https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/hamas-political-leader-ismail-haniyeh-killed-in-iran-5723ad8b?mod=hp_lead_pos1)
     from the original on 31 July 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731034454/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/31/hamass-political-chief-ismail-haniyeh-assassinated-in-iran-state-media)
     from the original on 31 July 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731040020/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/world-news/2024/07/31/israel-hamas-war-latest-news-leader-ismail-haniyeh-killed/)
     from the original on 31 July 2024."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article discusses the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran, Iran, on July 31, 2024. <image:26> The attack was carried out by Israel. The article mentions that Haniyeh was killed in his accommodation in a military-run guesthouse. The article also includes reactions from various parties, including Hamas, Iran, and Israel.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 2

The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record

Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp): 
Content: "[Skip to main content](#main-content)

Ismail Haniyeh’s Assassination: Escalation or an Off-Ramp?
==========================================================

     !Photo: Iranian Supreme Leader's Press Office via Getty Images <image:4045>

Photo: Iranian Supreme Leader's Press Office via Getty Images

*   [](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](https://x.com/intent/post?url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](mailto:?subject=Page from CSIS.org&body=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](javascript:window.print())
    

Commentary by [Riley McCabe](/people/riley-mccabe)

Published August 1, 2024

Remote Visualization

Ismail Haniyeh, the head of Hamas’s political wing, was killed by an [explosion](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/01/world/middleeast/how-hamas-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-bomb.html)
 in his guesthouse in the Iranian capital of Tehran on July 31, 2024. Immediately following the assassination, Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a [statement](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/31/irans-khamenei-vows-harsh-punishment-for-israel-after-haniyeh-killing)
, “We consider it our duty to avenge his blood in this bitter and difficult incident that happened in the territory of the Islamic Republic.” In April and May 2024, Israel and Iran exchanged long-range strikes in a rare instance of direct confrontation between the two states. As journalist Oz Katerji [put it](https://twitter.com/OzKaterji/status/1818610790108135631)
, “Israel is now just one Sinwar assassination away from being able to declare a ‘victory’ over Hamas in Gaza.”

In this way, Israel’s latest assassination appears to be a calculated risk on behalf of Netanyahu, who very likely personally approved the [operation](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/01/world/middleeast/how-hamas-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-bomb.html)
 to kill Haniyeh. All rights reserved.

* * *

, [Counterterrorism and Homeland Security](/topics/defense-and-security/counterterrorism-and-homeland-security)
, [Defense Strategy and Capabilities](/topics/defense-and-security/defense-strategy-and-capabilities)
, [Transnational Threats](/topics/transnational-threats)
, [Geopolitics and International Security](/topics/geopolitics-and-international-security)
, and [Terrorism and Irregular Warfare](/topics/terrorism-and-irregular-warfare)

### [Riley McCabe](/people/riley-mccabe)

Associate Fellow, Warfare, Irregular Threats, and Terrorism Program

### Programs & Projects

*   [Warfare, Irregular Threats, and Terrorism Program](/programs/warfare-irregular-threats-and-terrorism-program)
    
*   [International Security Program](/programs/international-security-program)
    
*   [Defense and Security](/defense-and-security) On the other, Haniyeh’s death delivers the Israeli government an important political victory that could open the door to reducing military operations in Gaza on its own terms.

Haniyeh had led Hamas’s political wing since 2017, serving as the group’s public face and overseeing its [finances](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2023/11/02/hamas-funding-ismail-haniyeh-us-sanctions/)
. Haniyeh was based in Qatar but was visiting Tehran for the inauguration of Iran’s new president when he was killed.

The assassination of Haniyeh is just the latest in a string of Israeli efforts to [hunt down](https://www.timesofisrael.com/in-recording-shin-bet-chief-vows-to-kill-hamas-chiefs-in-lebanon-turkey-qatar/)
 members of Hamas’s leadership for their involvement in the group’s attack on October 7, 2023. Still, there is always the risk that serious retaliation from Iran over Haniyeh’s assassination could tip the region into a broader war.

Haniyeh’s death also complicates peace talks over Gaza. In the near term, his assassination will undermine the [recent progress](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/28/world/middleeast/negotiators-meet-in-rome-to-revive-push-for-hostage-release-and-cease-fire-in-gaza.html)
 made between the two sides. Peace needs serious partners.”

However, in the long term, Haniyeh’s assassination and the killing of other senior Hamas leaders could serve as a path for Israel to reduce its military operations in Gaza. The assassinations of Haniyeh and Deif make this path appear increasingly credible."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) published an article on August 1, 2024, discussing the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh on July 31, 2024, in Tehran. The article mentions that Haniyeh was killed by an explosion in his guesthouse. <image:4045> shows a photo of Ismail Haniyeh. The article also discusses potential implications, including the risk of retaliation from Iran and the impact on peace talks.

Israeli hostage relative on her ‘worst fear’ after assassination of Hamas political leader

01:31 \- Source: [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/)

Israeli hostage relative on her ‘worst fear’ after assassination of Hamas political leader

01:31

*   Hamas said its [political leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/07/30/middleeast/hamas-political-leader-ismail-haniyeh-killed-intl-hnk/index.html)
     in an Israeli strike in the Iranian capital of Tehran, a major development that throws the region into an unpredictable and dangerous new phase.
*   Israel has neither confirmed nor denied being behind Haniyeh’s assassination. headquarters in New York on November 27, 2023.

Kyodo/AP/File

Israel will not be invited to a ceremony in Japan commemorating the 1945 atomic bombing of Nagasaki city, according to Japanese news agency Kyodo News, which cited the city’s mayor Shiro Suzuki.

In June, Suzuki sent a letter to Israel calling for a ceasefire in Gaza, leaving an invitation to the annual peace ceremony on hold due to a risk of “unexpected situations” such as protests, according to Kyodo News.

At a press conference on Wednesday, Suzuki said he had not seen any changes that would lessen those risks ahead of the August 9 ceremony promoting world peace.

Israel’s Ambassador to Japan, Gilad Cohen, described the decision as “regrettable” in a post on X, adding it “sends a wrong message to the world.” 

In contrast, Hiroshima has invited Israel to its annual ceremony on August 6, a decision that’s been controversial with activists and atomic bomb survivors’ groups that say Israel should be excluded this year as Russia and Belarus have been for the past two years over Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.

Israel’s representative Jonathan Miller speaks at the UN Security Council on Wednesday, July 31 in New York.

UNTV

Israel’s representative speaking at the UN Security Council, Jonathan Miller, urged the United Nations to “hold the Islamic Republic accountable for its crimes” related to its support of groups like Hezbollah and Hamas. 

Miller called Iran “the very engine driving the machinery of death and destruction that threatens us all.”  

Israel has neither confirmed nor denied being behind the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh.

![Feda Abdelhady Nasser, the deputy permanent observer of the State of Palestine to the UN, speaks during a UN Security Council meeting at the United Nations Headquarters on Wednesday, July 31, in New York City. ](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/1eb8b2f9-5686-46bc-9f56-7b3e4396ec73.jpg?c=original&q=w_1280,c_fill)

Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei speaks after casting his vote for the presidential runoff election on July 5 in Tehran, Iran.

Majid Saeedi/Getty Images/File

Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has issued an order for Iran to “strike Israel directly” following the killing of Hamas’ political leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran overnight, [according to the New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/middleeast/iran-orders-attack-israel.html)
. 

The Times, citing information it said was provided by three Iranian officials familiar with the order, said the directive was given during an emergency meeting for Iran’s Supreme National Security Council Wednesday. 

The New York Times said the officials asked not to be named because they did not have the authority to speak publicly. The report did not say how or when any strike would be carried out.

Earlier, Khamenei said it was Iran’s “duty” to avenge Haniyeh’s death since he was killed inside Iran. 

“You killed our dear guest in our house and now have paved the way for your harsh punishment,” he said in a statement, referring to Israel. 

[](mailto:?subject=New%20York%20Times%3A%20Iran's%20supreme%20leader%20orders%20direct%20attack%20on%20Israel%20after%20killing%20of%20Hamas%20leader&body=Checkout%20the%20latest%20news%20from%20CNN%3A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2Fworld%2Flive-news%2Fhamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24%23h_a162d5f7f74543675685f7a84f72646d "Share with email")

Link Copied!

CNN reviewed statements by Hamas and others, in addition to state media outlets and other social media posts, to analyze and track the Islamist militant group leader Ismail Haniyeh’s movements since October 7, 2023.

After he celebrated seeing his fighters return to the Gaza Strip with Israeli equipment in Hamas’ office in Istanbul, Turkey on October 7, Ismail Haniyeh spent the majority of his time in Doha as head of Hamas’ Political Bureau but took a number of trips to Tehran, Istanbul and Cairo, according to a CNN analysis.

**Tehran:** Haniyeh took at least four trips to Tehran – in November, March, May and July. During all four visits, he met with Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei.

In May, he attended the funerals of Iranian president Ebrahim Raisi and foreign minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, who were killed in a helicopter crash. 

On his final trip to Tehran, which ended with his assassination, he was attending the inauguration of the new Iranian president Masoud Pezeshkian.

**Cairo:** He also took three known trips to Cairo in November, December and February, to lead Hamas’ ceasefire negotiating delegation. That negotiation process, which is still ongoing, has been shepherded by Qatar and Egypt.  

**Doha:** As war ravaged Gaza, Haniyeh spent the majority of his time in Hamas’ Doha offices. While there, press statements from Hamas indicate he repeatedly met with a number of foreign dignitaries, gave speeches and held meetings.

Doha is also where Haniyeh issued his first statement after his three sons, and four grandchildren were killed in Gaza by an Israeli airstrike. In that statement from mid-April, he said that such killings will only make Hamas more steadfast in its principles, adding that Hamas will not surrender, will not compromise, no matter how great the sacrifice.

[](mailto:?subject=Where%20the%20assassinated%20Hamas%20leader%20Ismail%20Haniyeh%20spent%20the%20months%20after%20October%207&body=Checkout%20the%20latest%20news%20from%20CNN%3A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2Fworld%2Flive-news%2Fhamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24%23h_590757f133c13009d93ed745dc294aaf "Share with email")

    , saying his country is “ready for any scenario” and has delivered “crushing blows” to its enemies.
*   Haniyeh was the second figure of an Iran-backed group assassinated in the past day, following the [killing by Israel of a senior Hezbollah commander](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/30/middleeast/beirut-explosion-hezbollah-stronghold-intl-latam/index.html)
     in Lebanon.
*   Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei [vowed to avenge Haniyeh’s death.](https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/hamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24#h_eaa90d54d3f74eb4d834d0007861a9ee)
      “You killed our dear guest in our house and now have paved the way for your harsh punishment,” he said, referring to Israel. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the US was [“not aware of or involved in”](https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/hamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24#h_6068f906b960c90e07a625a64d4fdba9)

Temporary flight restrictions have been issued in Tehran ahead of a memorial procession on Thursday for assassinated Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh.

The notice issued by Iran’s Civil Aviation Organisation restricts flight movements within a 2-kilometer (0.6-mile) circle radius centered at the University of Tehran.

Flight restrictions will be in place from 6 a.m. Israel has neither confirmed nor denied being behind Haniyeh’s assassination.

“Israel was also pursuing \[a\] political goal with this act, aiming to disrupt the first day of the new government of the Islamic Republic of Iran, which has prioritized strengthening peace and stability in the region, and enhancing cooperation and constructive engagement with international community,” Iravani added.

A relative of a hostage still being held in Gaza has said it is “hard to see” how the assassination of Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh will help advance the deal to secure the release of the remaining hostages. 

Sharone Lifschitz, whose 83-year-old father Oded has been held in Gaza since October 7, said that she trusted statements from Qatari meditators on Wednesday warning that Haniyeh’s killing “doesn’t help” the talks between Israel and Hamas. 

She told CNN that her confidence is waning in the ability of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to broker a deal to return the hostages. Lifschitz’s 85-year-old mother was previously released from captivity in Gaza.

Netanyahu’s priority now, according to Lifschitz, is not securing the release of the hostages but rather shoring up his own “political survival.” She said she has “no sympathy” for Netanyahu himself, only for the hostages, their families, and the “innocent civilians caught up in this nightmare.”

The military wing of Hamas said it had carried out “two shooting operations” near the city of Hebron in the occupied West Bank on Wednesday in response to the killing of the group’s political leader Ismail Haniyeh.  

The Al Qassam Brigades said it was “the beginning of a swift response to the cowardly assassination of our great national leader, the martyr Ismail Haniyeh.”

“Hebron will lead the way in carrying out qualitative operations in the coming days, by the will of Allah,” it added.

The Israel Defense Forces said a civilian was in the hospital after being shot at and stabbed northeast of Hebron.

Israel’s Magen David Adom (MDA) emergency service said a 50-year-old man was hospitalized in serious condition after being stabbed on Route 60 near Kiryat Arba, a settlement on the outskirts of Hebron."

The CSIS article mentions that Haniyeh was killed by an explosion in his guesthouse ([https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp](https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)).

Another image is from clickondetroit.com ([https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/2025/06/22/iranian-missile-fired-after-us-strikes-causes-heavy-damage-but-few-injuries-in-tel-aviv/](https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/2025/06/22/iranian-missile-fired-after-us-strikes-causes-heavy-damage-but-few-injuries-in-tel-aviv/)). The third image is from Axios ([https://www.axios.com/2022/10/11/russia-missile-strikes-ukraine](https://www.axios.com/2022/10/11/russia-missile-strikes-ukraine)). <image:9507>, <image:9508>, <image:9509>

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:26>)
web_search("Ismail Haniyeh assassination July 31 2024")
image_search("building damage missile strike")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `geolocate`
The most likely countries where the image was taken are: {'Cambodia': 0.35, 'Pakistan': 0.1, 'Bangladesh': 0.07, 'Ghana': 0.07, 'Bhutan': 0.06, 'China': 0.05, 'Sri Lanka': 0.04, 'Albania': 0.03, 'Kyrgyzstan': 0.02, 'Laos': 0.02}

### Evidence from `web_search`
The provided sources discuss the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran, Iran, on July 31, 2024. The attack was carried out by Israel, according to Wikipedia ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh)). The CSIS article mentions that Haniyeh was killed by an explosion in his guesthouse ([https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp](https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)).

CNN reports that Israel has neither confirmed nor denied being behind the assassination ([https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/hamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24](https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/hamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24)). The image <image:26>

### Evidence from `image_search`
The web search results include images of buildings damaged by missile strikes. One image is from a PBS article ([https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/more-russian-missiles-slam-ukrainian-apartments-killing-13-in-zaporizhzhia](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/more-russian-missiles-slam-ukrainian-apartments-killing-13-in-zaporizhzhia)). Another image is from clickondetroit.com ([https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/2025/06/22/iranian-missile-fired-after-us-strikes-causes-heavy-damage-but-few-injuries-in-tel-aviv/](https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/2025/06/22/iranian-missile-fired-after-us-strikes-causes-heavy-damage-but-few-injuries-in-tel-aviv/)). The third image is from Axios ([https://www.axios.com/2022/10/11/russia-missile-strikes-ukraine](https://www.axios.com/2022/10/11/russia-missile-strikes-ukraine)). <image:9507>, <image:9508>, <image:9509>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim states that the image shows the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. The web search confirms that Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated on July 31, 2024, in Tehran, Iran. However, the image geolocation suggests the image was taken in Cambodia, Pakistan, or other countries, not Iran. The evidence does not confirm that the image depicts the assassination.

The claim also describes the nature of the strike. The image search shows other images of buildings damaged by missile strikes. However, the evidence does not confirm the nature of the strike in the image.

Therefore, the claim is not supported by the evidence. The location of the image does not match the location of the assassination.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

The image search results show other images of buildings damaged by missile strikes, but the evidence does not confirm that the image depicts the assassination.
